sub_title: Director: Development and Consultancy at CHEPS, University of Twente
summary:
Interests and professional background
Jon File holds a first-class Honours degree in Sociology from the University of Cape Town. His career has been primarily in university planning and management, having held the posts of Director of Academic Support Programmes, University Planning Officer and Academic Secretary at the University of Cape Town between 1980 and 1997. He was a member of the 13-person National Commission on Higher Education (1995/6) appointed by the new South African government to make proposals for the transformation of higher education. He joined CHEPS as Director of Development and Consultancy in 1998 and served as Executive Director from 2004 to 2009.

Major projects
Jon File’s major project involvement is in policy oriented and development projects. He has been the project leader of ten extensive capacity development projects in South Africa, Ethiopia, Uganda and Mozambique (total budget over €12 million) at both institutional and system levels. He has coordinated numerous seminars and tailor-made courses for university leaders and members of national ministries including four multi-year workshop series on higher education policy for HE leaders from Hungary, the Czech Republic, Poland, Slovenia and other (then) EU pre-accession countries. He has also run projects in Estonia, Russia, Indonesia, Yemen and Portugal.
In 2006 he was the co-project leader for two European Commission projects on higher education
reforms (curriculum and governance) across 32 European countries, and a member of the OECD
review teams for higher education in the Czech Republic and Portugal. In 2009/10 he was again coproject leader for EC funded projects on higher education reform across Europe (Bologna process; governance; and funding) and on the development of a global multi-dimensional university ranking (UMultirank).

projects.title: 1983 - 1995: Senior University Management and Administration (UCT)
projects.description:
•	I had over a decade's experience in senior university management at a major South African university during a period of immense change. (The university then enrolled some 15 000 students in ten faculties on 4 campuses.) While my direct responsibilities were in the areas of academic policy, planning and administration, my membership of the Vice-Chancellor's executive management group and my periods of office as Acting Registrar gave me a broad exposure to all aspects of university management including finance, human resource management, industrial relations, physical planning, public relations and student affairs. This overall perspective on university management was strengthened by attendance at meetings of Council, Senate, Budget Committee and senior planning committees over a 10-year period.

•	Within the broad area of academic administration I have particular experience in the fields of planning, information systems, careers services, student financial aid (including the establishment of a major loan scheme with a commercial bank), the development of flexible selection mechanisms and undergraduate programmes for a heterogeneous student body, and major reviews of academic programmes.

projects.title: 1986 - 1996: International Experience in Higher Education (UCT)
projects.description:

•	1987: I attended Geoffrey Lockwood's two week British Council course on University Planning and Management in Brighton, England.

•	1994 - 1996: Organising Secretary for the Tenth International Meeting of University Administrators which was held in Cape Town in January 1996 and which was attended by 300 delegates from 60 countries.
•	1996 - 1997: South African representative for the Commonwealth Higher Education Management Service (CHEMS), a project based at the Association of Commonwealth Universities, London.
•	1996 - 1997: South African co-ordinator of a European Union funded research project on management capacity in South African and EU higher education. The project was undertaken by the Center for Higher Education Policy Studies, University of Twente, the Netherlands.

projects.title: European policy orientated higher education research projects (CHEPS)
projects.description:
In 2006 I was the co-project leader (with Jürgen Enders, Director of CHEPS) for two European Commission projects on higher education reforms (curriculum and governance) across 32 European countries. As with my work in developing countries I also functioned as a key expert in the governance reform project.
 
In 2009/10 I was again co-project leader (with Jürgen Enders) for three European Commission funded projects on higher education reform in 33 countries across Europe (Bologna process [46 countries]; governance; and funding) where in the latter two projects I was again a key expert. 

In 2010/11 I was the co-project leader (with Frans van Vught and Frank Ziegele) of the European Commission funded feasibility study on the development of a global multi-dimensional university ranking (U-Multirank) and I am currently one of the four project leaders for the 4-year U-Multirank implementation project launched by the Commission in January 2013. 

In 2014/5 I am the co-project leader (with Hans Vossensteyn) of a European Commission funded project on higher education drop-out and completion in 36 European countries.

These eight projects for the European Commission had budgets totalling €7 million. 

In 2006 I was appointed by the OECD as an expert member of the review teams for higher education in the Czech Republic and Portugal. In the former I was also the rapporteur. 

Apart from these major projects I have played a key role in the development of U-Map (a university activity profiling tool); acted as a context expert in the OECD’s international assessment of higher education learning outcomes project (AHELO); and have led a range of smaller research and policy projects.

projects.title: Higher education development projects (CHEPS)
projects.description:
I have been the project leader of ten extensive capacity development projects in South Africa, Ethiopia, Uganda and Mozambique (total budget over €12 million) at both institutional and system levels. With one exception (a project on quality assurance in Mozambique) I have also been the principal expert within these projects which have focused on institutional governance and management; the development of steering instruments and capacity in the Ministries responsible for higher education; and on the reform of higher education funding. I have also run projects in Indonesia and Yemen.

In terms of ongoing involvement in South African higher education, three of the capacity development projects were with the (then) Technikon Northern Gauteng (1997 - 2003). I have subsequently worked as an individual planning consultant to the Tshwane University of Technology (2004 - 2008) and the University of Venda (ongoing since 2007). Since 1997 I have made 66 work-related visits to South Africa.

projects.title: Leadership and Management Development in Higher Education (CHEPS)
projects.description:
I have coordinated numerous seminars and tailor-made courses for university leaders and members of national ministries including four multi-year workshop series (between 1999 and 2005) on higher education policy for higher education leaders from Hungary, the Czech Republic, Poland, Slovenia and the six other (then) EU pre-accession countries. 

I have been a core lecturer on the European Consortium of Innovative Universities (ECIU) Leadership Development Programme since 2006 and from 2010 a contributor to the University of Georgia (USA) professional doctorate in higher education management. Since 2009 I have been a (visiting) Senior Fellow of the L.H. Martin Institute for Higher Education Leadership and Management at the University of Melbourne, Australia and a regular presenter on its Masters programme. 

A notable feature of my work in these different leadership development activities has been the design of a series of higher education leadership simulation games that have been played in 20 countries by over 1000 participants from 45 different nationalities.

profile_positions.description: In addition to my full-time positions I served as Warden in two different university residences. l was the first Warden of The Woolsack, a community of senior men and women students, and Warden of Smuts Hall, the university's premier undergraduate hall of residence for men. Both positions entailed hands-on involvement in the creation of non-racial academic communities and in working with student leadership to create democratic and effective forms of residence governance.
profile_positions.title: Warden: The Woolsack & Warden: Smuts Hall

profile_positions.description:
•	Head of the Academic Administration, a department of 80 members of staff responsible for the provision of professional and administrative services in the following areas: admissions procedures and policy; the computerised student record system; careers advice; undergraduate and postgraduate student financial support; academic planning; research support and contracts; and the academic administration of the university’s ten faculties.

•	The Academic Secretary was also the senior Deputy to the Registrar [acting as Registrar in his absence] and a member of the Vice-Chancellor’s executive management group.

•	In 1993 the Academic Secretary's job description was revised to give a greater focus to academic policy and planning matters, and to the integration of academic, physical and financial planning. Direct line management responsibility for other functions was transferred to the new post of Deputy Registrar (Academic & Research).

•	In January 1995 I was appointed to the National Commission on Higher Education. While remaining Academic Secretary, and undertaking particular projects for the university, l was seconded to the commission on a major time basis until August 1996. I took accumulated and study leave until mid-1997, when I resigned as Academic Secretary to move to CHEPS.
